column1: Bounded Suboptimal Search with Learned Heuristics for Multi-Agent Systems
Markus Spies@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
column2: Marco Todescato@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
column3: Hannes Becker@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
column4: Patrick Kesper@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
column5: Nicolai Waniek@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
column6: Meng Guo@Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence

column1: AAAI Technical Track: Heuristic Search and Optimization
A wide range of discrete planning problems can be solved optimally using graph search algorithms. However
column2: optimal search quickly becomes infeasible with increased complexity of a problem. In such a case
column3: heuristics that guide the planning process towards the goal state can increase performance considerably. Unfortunately
column4: heuristics are often unavailable or need manual and time-consuming engineering. Building upon recent results on applying deep learning to learn generalized reactive policies
column5: we propose to learn heuristics by imitation learning. After learning heuristics based on optimal examples
column6: they are used to guide a classical search algorithm to solve unseen tasks. However
column7: directly applying learned heuristics in search algorithms such as A∗ breaks optimality guarantees
column8: since learned heuristics are not necessarily admissible. Therefore
column9: we (i) propose a novel method that utilizes learned heuristics to guide Focal Search A∗
column10: a variant of A∗ with guarantees on bounded suboptimality; (ii) compare the complexity and performance of jointly learning individual policies for multiple robots with an approach that learns one policy for all robots; (iii) thoroughly examine how learned policies generalize to previously unseen environments and demonstrate considerably improved performance in a simulated complex dynamic coverage problem.
